That’s why I pushed to create the NBRC Regional Forest Economy Partnership. New funds will help a biomass heat and power plant in #Brattleboro, forestry programs at @VTtech, an ag business network at @VermontHCB & a regional destination initiative from the @northern_forest ctr.

But recent downtown turns in wood markets have taken a toll.  We need new solutions, new markets and sustained federal investment to ensure our rural communities can capitalize on new opportunities and retain their vibrancy.

Today we are also marking the first NBRC awards that invest specifically in our #forest based economy. For generations, many communities across Vermont, northern New York and New England relied heavily on the economic benefits of the forest economy.

Federal grants will support the redevelopment of Main St in @Winooskivt, infrastructure in Newport, Burke, St. Albans & Randolph.  Childcare & workforce efforts supported by @LetsGrowKids & @VTRoundtable.

We chose Springfield for this announcement because of @BRICvt. Their coworking & incubation space, & goal of growing startups in VT, is the type of project I had in mind when I expanded NBRC in the #FarmBill so all of VT would be eligible. They are receiving a $235k grant.

In Springfield today to announce more than $7.9 million in grants from @NBRC_Team to boost job growth in #VT.  These funds will help grow our workforce, repair our infrastructure & give Vermont workers new skills for the modern economy.

And all this for a bill that will NEVER BECOME LAW. We all agree we need a secure border. We all agree migrants must be treated humanely. Dems stand ready to work with Rs in good faith, like I did as chairman in 2013. Today’s partisan fiasco did nothing to solve these issues.

We've all seen the pictures of the awful conditions in CBP custody. I’ve seen them first-hand. I wanted to create a multi-agency migrant processing center to reduce overcrowding and speed processing. This should be a nonpartisan no-brainer. Graham didn't allow it.

If “the cruelty is the point” of the Trump administration’s immigration policies, allowing for the indefinite detention of children would be its posterchild. I wanted to introduce an amendment stripping indefinite detention from the Graham bill. Graham didn't allow it.

Even Chairman Graham this morning acknowledged that we need to deal with the conditions in the Northern Triangle. I wanted to offer the Central America Reform and Enforcement Act to do just that. Graham didn't allow it.

The Committee should start the immigration reform debate where we left off in 2013. Then, as chairman, I held five markups and 30 hours of debate. We considered 100s of amendments, and accepted almost 50 from Republicans. That’s why we received 68 bipartisan votes on the floor.

Democrats had many serious, substantive proposals for how to fix the problems that plague our immigration system and border.  We filed over 100 amendments. Graham broke every rule and didn’t allow us to offer any.  Here’s a couple I wanted to offer—

Chairman Graham just broke FOUR committee rules in order to advance Pres. Trump’s bill to lock up immigrant children INDEFINITELY. Rules every Republican voted for 6 months ago. Rules I always respected as chairman. 

They might as well rip them up. So I did it for them. pic.twitter.com/SCjnFLSOtE

Chairman Graham just broke Judiciary Committee rules to advance Trump bill to indefinitely detain immigrant children. Senator Leahy will be speaking on this momentarily. LIVE on @CSPAN and at https://www.judiciary.senate.gov/meetings/08/01/2019/executive-business-meeting …

.@SenatorLeahy, @SenatorCollins And @SenatorDurbin Reintroduce Bipartisan Legislation To Combat Illegal Straw Purchasing And Firearms Trafficking --   https://www.leahy.senate.gov/press/leahy-collins-and-durbin-reintroduce-bipartisan-legislation-to-combat-illegal-straw-purchasing_and-firearms-trafficking …

I just reintroduced my firearms trafficking bill, with Senators Collins and Durbin, to provide critical tools to prosecute straw purchasers and gun traffickers. This bill received 58 votes in 2013. The Senate should pass this bipartisan first step without delay.

Gun violence plagues our nation. There’s already been 98 killings in DC this year. The police chief has blamed the spike on easy access to illegal guns. For too long, we have allowed criminals to obtain firearms through unregulated markets and traffickers. We must act.
